Posts.Content: flfish wrote: I had my biopsy last Thursday, 3/20/08 (Birad 4).  My surgeon just called me and told me I had intraductal cancer.  I am under the impression that this means that it is not yet invasive is that correct?  I have an appointment Wednesday, but any information I can get before that appointment (so I can ask the right questions) would be very helpful.  Is radiation a standard treatment for this?  My mother passed away from breast cancer, and I know she was treated with Tamoxofin and the side effects were not pleasant.  Any info would be appreciated.  I am so glad that I have found this site for support.  Thank you. Dx 3/24/2008, DCIS, 2cm, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy results flfish flfish

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2008 06:37PM flfish wrote: Thank you for the quick responses.  I will check out the DCIS discussion forum as  you pointed out and let you know what happens Wednesday.  Thanks again for all the support
Posts.Title: Biopsy results flfish flfish

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 04:33AM flfish wrote: Thanks for asking the question Kim.  I am having a lumpectomy and SNB tomorrow morning, and a lot of my own questions were answered in this conversation.  Good luck to you and here's to a B9 outcome Ellie
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 05:54PM flfish wrote: Kim- I hope your surgery goes as well as mine did.  I had a lumpectomy and SNB this morning and I am amazed at how good I feel.  I was sore when I first work up, but once the meds kicked in, no problems.  No drains for me, but I only had one node removed (NEGATIVE---YIPPEE) so I was lucky.  I found that I am extremely relieved that is it over.  Knowing IS better than waiting.  Best of luck to you! Ellie
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 12:56PM flfish wrote: J--we seem to be close.  I am having my lumpectomy on April 21 in Naples.  I am 40 and after going in for my very first "routine" mammogram 3 weeks ago, I am now facing this.  It is very scary, but oddly comforting to know that so many of us are all going through surgery around the same time.  Best of luck to all of us Ellie

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2008 02:39PM flfish wrote: I am glad others have said about the cough.  I am only on my second week, and I noticed a slight cough along with shortness of breath.  Is this normal?  I will see the oncologist Wednesday after my treatment and discuss this with him as well, I was just wondering if others noticed this as well.  I guess I wasn't aware that rads would compromise our immune systems.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2008 09:47AM flfish wrote: Dimple, I am so sorry you had to go back.  I got lucky.  I had my lumpectomy on 4/21 and they had clear margins so no going back for me, just off to radiation.  I will be praying for you through the weekend.  Here's to good clean results come Wednesday! Ellie
Posts.Title: breast needle localization Dimplesmur twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 12:45PM flfish wrote: Pam--for months after my lumpectomy I wore a cotton sports bra (that snapped in the front).  I went to Wal-Mart and bought 5 cheap ones.  I found them to be very helpful while going through radiation as well, and since they are so easy to wash, I didn't mind getting some of the lotion and medicine on them.  Best of luck to you! Ellie
Posts.Title: what type of a bra did you wear after your lumpectomy? aris Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 04:13AM flfish wrote: Brena....I swim and I have not had a problem.  However, I have a saltwater pool and I make sure to rinse off right away.  I don't know about the tanning, but I would think you would want to stay away from that.  I live in south Florida, and every time I am out in the sun, I am wearing spf 30 just to be safe.  I think our skin is getting enough exposure through the rads.
Posts.Title: top ten things I learned with rads juliajo flfish

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 07:48AM flfish wrote: The waiting is the hardest part.  We have all been there at one time.  Please use this post to help educate yourself on the calcifications and try and pass the time.  Wishing you B9 results on Wednesday.  Remember, 80% are benign and you are young and strong and you can take this!!
